LedeIn:
This year's election cycle will be the first in decades where Montana voters get to select not one but two U.S. Representatives to advocate for the state's interests in Congress. Also on the ballot this year is control of the Montana Legislature, two seats on the state's utility regulation board and two seats on the Montana Supreme Court

The first step for the political hopefulls is the **June 7 primary election**, where Montana voters will choose the candidates to represent each of the state's recognized political parties in the **Nov. 8 general election** (independent candidates can qualify for the November ballot if they collect enough signatures).
BallotMeasuresIntro:
This year's ballot initiatives will be placed on the November general election ballot. We'll update this page with more information about the measures that qualify for the 2022 ballot in summer or early fall.

In the meantime, information proposed ballot measures is available [on the Montana Secretary of State's website](https://sosmt.gov/elections/ballot_issues/proposed-2022-ballot-issues/).
LegislativeIntro: Montanans elect 100 state representatives to two-year terms and 25 of 50 state senators to four-year terms in each even-year election. In 2022, one additional senate district (SD 15) is also on the ballot to fill the vacancy left by [Sen. Ryan Osmundson's appointment](https://montanafreepress.org/2021/09/07/montana-budget-director-kurt-alme-resigns/) as the governor's budget director.
